raw_text:
Wales silent on Grand Slam talk
 
 Rhys Williams says Wales are still not thinking of winning the Grand Slam despite a third Six Nations win.
 
 "That's the last thing on our minds at the moment," said Williams, a second- half replacement in Saturday's 24-18 win over France in Paris. "We all realise how difficult a task it is to go up to Scotland and beat them. "We've come unstuck there a couple of times recently so our focus is on that game and we'll worry about Ireland hopefully after we've beaten Scotland." With captain Gareth Thomas ruled out of the rest of the campaign with a broken thumb, Williams is vying for his first start in the championship so far.
 
 Kevin Morgan is probably favourite to replace Thomas at full-back, leaving Williams and Hal Luscombe to battle for the right wing berth. A hamstring injury denied Luscombe the opportunity to make a third successive start, but the Dragons winger is expected to be fit for the trip to Murrayfield on 13 March. Hooker Robin McBryde is doubtful after picking up a knee injury in Paris, but centre Sonny Parker and flanker Colin Charvis are set to recover from injury to be in contention for selection. Said Wales assistant coach Scott Johnson: "They've worked through the weekend and the reports are a bit more positive. "So we're getting a couple back and that adds to the depth of the squad." Scotland secured their first win of the campaign on Saturday by grinding out an 18-10 win over Italy.
 
 Matt Williams' side has shown little in attack, but Johnson insisted the Scots will be difficult opposition to break down. "Italy are really brave opposition and sometimes it's very hard to win," he said. "So an ugly win can be just as effective as a 30 or 40 point victory. "Scotland are a hard side and very underrated so we're not taking anything for granted. "We're not basking in the glory of winning our first three games. We've got to be diligent in our preparation. "That's my job and we've got to make sure we're focused."
llama3.2:1b:
Wales are considering their options after a third Six Nations win, but captain Gareth Thomas is ruled out for the rest of the campaign due to a broken thumb.

Rhys Williams is vying for his first start in the championship, with Kevin Morgan and Hal Luscombe competing for the right wing berth. 

Scotland secured their first win of the season against Italy, with an "ugly" 18-10 victory being more effective than a 30-point margin.

Assistant coach Scott Johnson says Wales will be difficult to beat, but Scotland are considered hard to break down due to their bravery and underestimation by others.
llama3.2:3b: Wales are focusing on beating Scotland rather than talking about a Grand Slam, with Rhys Williams saying his team is not thinking about the championship title despite their recent wins. The side will face an injury-hit squad when captain Gareth Thomas is ruled out for the rest of the campaign. Assistant coach Scott Johnson believes Sonny Parker and Colin Charvis are set to recover from injuries to boost the team's depth. Scotland secured their first win of the campaign with a 18-10 victory over Italy, who are being praised by Johnson for their bravery and difficulty to beat.
gemma2:2b: Wales is focusing on their upcoming match against Scotland, despite a 3rd win in the Six Nations.  Welsh players are not thinking of winning the Grand Slam but will focus on beating Scotland before considering Ireland. Kevin Morgan and Hal Luscombe are battling for the right wing spot, while Robin McBryde is doubtful with a knee injury.  Wales assistant coach Scott Johnson highlights the challenges of facing Scotland, emphasizing that an "ugly" win can be just as effective as a large victory.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
Key points:

- Wales are still not thinking about their Grand Slam victory despite a third Six Nations win.
- Rhys Williams says the Wales team is focusing on Scotland's game against them rather than going up to Scotland.
- Kevin Morgan, Gareth Thomas, and Sonny Parker are expected to return for Wales' next match at Murrayfield.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Wales' focus remains on upcoming matches against Scotland and Ireland rather than considering a Grand Slam victory as they are still struggling with their performance against Scotland recently.
qwen2.5:3b: Wales are focusing on their upcoming match against Scotland, considering it more challenging than the Grand Slam due to recent defeats. Captain Gareth Thomas is out with a broken thumb, leaving Rhys Williams as a potential second-half replacement candidate for full-back. Wales' assistant coach Scott Johnson noted that several players like Robin McBryde and Sonny Parker are expected back from injuries, adding depth to the squad. Despite their early wins in the Six Nations, Johnson stressed the need for diligence in preparation against Scotland, who scored an 18-10 win over Italy on Saturday.

"Rhys Williams says Wales are still not thinking of winning the Grand Slam despite a third Six Nations win."

- Rhys Williams said that Wales aren't thinking about winning the Grand Slam.
- "That's the last thing on our minds at the moment," said Williams, a second-half replacement in Saturday's 24-18 win over France in Paris.
- He also mentioned that we all realise how difficult a task it is to go up to Scotland and beat them. We've come unstuck there a couple of times recently so our focus is on that game and we'll worry about Ireland hopefully after we've beaten Scotland.
- However, with captain Gareth Thomas ruled out of the rest of the campaign with a broken thumb, Williams is vying for his first start in the championship so far.
- Kevin Morgan has likely been the favourite to replace Thomas at full-back, leaving Williams and Hal Luscombe to battle for the right wing berth. A hamstring injury denied Luscombe the opportunity to make a third successive start, but the Dragons winger is expected to be fit for the trip to Murrayfield on 13 March.
- Hooker Robin McBryde has been doubtful after picking up a knee injury in Paris, but centre Sonny Parker and flanker Colin Charvis are likely set to recover from injury to be in contention for selection. 
- Said Wales assistant coach Scott Johnson: "They've worked through the weekend and the reports are a bit more positive. They're getting a couple back and that adds to the depth of the squad."
- Scotland has secured their first win of the campaign on Saturday by grinding out an 18-10 win over Italy.
- Matt Williams' side has shown little in attack, but Johnson insisted the Scots will be difficult opposition to break down. "Italy are really brave opposition and sometimes it's very hard to win," he said.
smollm:1.7b: The summary is concise, preserving key ideas and details while omitting unnecessary information. It provides a clear overview of the text without adding or changing its meaning. The summary should also be free from any explanations, formatting, or reasoning processes.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Alright, I need to summarize this text about Wales' upcoming Grand Slam campaign. Let me read through it carefully.

First, Rhys Williams says Wales aren't thinking of winning the Grand Slam despite their recent Six Nations win. He mentions they're not focusing on that for now. I should note that Wales haven't decided to take on the World Cup yet.

Next, Williams is from second-half replacements in Saturday's 24-18 win over France. He talks about how challenging it is to beat them up there and focuses on that game. He mentions worrying about Ireland after beating Scotland. That part is important because it shows his preparation ahead.

Looking at the other teams: Kevin Morgan could be replacing Williams for full-back, leaving Williams and Hal Luscombe for the right wing. Luscombe might be missing a start in Murrayfield but is expected to make it. Robert McBryde has a knee injury and needs to rest, so he's not selected yet.

The assistant coach says they've worked through things and there are some positive reports. They're building depth by getting back some players. Scotland won their first campaign win against Italy on Saturday, which helps Wales' case but isn't the main focus.

Wales' coach Scott Johnson emphasizes that it's a tough opposition from Italy. He wants Wales to prepare well because they've already secured their first three wins. They're not basking in victory yet and need to keep their preparation solid to fight back.

I should make sure the summary includes key points: Wales' focus on six games, no decision on Grand Slam, Williams' role, Luscombe's situation, Scotland's win, and the coach's views.
</think>

tinyllama:1.1b: Wales is not yet focusing on winning the Grand Slam despite their third Six Nations win, as they are still prioritizing the upcoming match against Scotland. The team has shown little attacking prowess in recent games but will have to be careful when dealing with the Italian opposition, who can sometimes be challenging opponents. Wales' head coach Scott Johnson emphasizes that despite a win, their focus is not yet on winning the Grand Slam.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The current Six Nations standings: Wales: Won 3, Lost 2; France: Won 3, Lost 1; Italy: Won 0, Lost 2; Ireland: Won 1, Lost 2. Wales are currently placed third in the table and will play against Scotland on March 13th.
phi:2.7b: Wales is currently not considering winning the Grand Slam despite a win against France, as they are focusing on their upcoming game against Scotland. Kevin Morgan has been given the chance to replace Gareth Thomas at full-back, while Williams and Hal Luscombe compete for the right wing berth. Robin McBryde's knee injury has ruled him out of the trip to Murrayfield, but Sonny Parker and Colin Charvis are expected to recover in time. Scotland defeated Italy in their first win of the campaign with a score of 18-10. Despite not being very active on the attack, Wales' coach Scott Johnson praised Scotland for being a tough opponent that can still result in an ugly win. They are taking their upcoming games seriously and preparing diligently.

Wales unmindful of Grand Slam discussions, focus on Scotland game
